awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Ion-Exchange Fiber Composites for Rapid and Selective Removal of Perchlorate from Water
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will result in the continuing development of novel ultrafast, highly selective, high permeability ion-exchange fiber composites (IXFCs) for removing perchlorate from drinking water. The proposed material removes perchlorate 10-100 times faster than the best available technology and employs a low-cost production method compatible with widely available manufacturing equipment. Rapid contaminant removal is made possible by the use of micron-scale mass transfer distances; whereas commonly used beads and granular media are limited to much larger sizes resulting in drawbacks such as difficult containment and enormous pressure drops. However, IXFCs display both high permeability and self-containment due to their permanently intertwined, self-supporting structure. Serionix demonstrated the feasibility of this technology in Phase I and will continue in the Phase II with the following key goals: 1) optimization of ultra-high capacity IXFCs for perchlorate removal; 2) design/build IXFC purification cartridges for evaluation by industrial partners; 3) identify and validate chemistries for complimentary IXFCs that are selective for heavy metals such as lead and mercury; and 4) produce IXFCs at a pilot scale and develop strategy for commercial production.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this research is the development and commercialization of a low-cost technology enabling regulatory compliance and improved protection of human health. The first targeted application is perchlorate, which the EPA is set to regulate in drinking water by 2014. This represents only the first commercial opportunity for a platform technology with the ultimate potential to transform the industrial and residential water treatment landscape. Future applications may include ultrahigh efficiency water deionization, softening, and industrial wastewater recycling, personal protective equipment and clothing, and high activity solid acid/base catalysts. Dissemination of data and interpretation will contribute to improved understanding of mass transfer characteristics in fibrous sorbent materials used in both water and air treatment.

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project resulted in the development of novel ultrafast, high permeability ion-exchange fiber composites (IXFCs) for removing toxic chemicals and odors from air. Our Colorfil? technology based on IXFCs employs a low-cost production method compatible with widely available manufacturing equipment, and removes airborne chemical contaminants more efficiently and with higher capacity than the best available competitive technology. Rapid contaminant removal is made possible by the use of micron-scale mass transfer distances; whereas commonly used ion-exchange beads and granular media are limited to much larger sizes resulting in drawbacks such as poor efficiency, high pressure drop, and additional containment requirements. However, IXFCs display high permeability and self-containment due to their permanently intertwined, self-supporting structure, allowing for direct use as a dual-purpose particulate and chemical filtration media.

 

Serionix demonstrated the basic feasibility of this technology against waterborne contaminants in Phase I but refocused development in Phase II and IIB towards air purification after extensive customer discovery activity. To that end, the following key goals were met: 1) optimization of ultra-high capacity IXFCs for alkaline and acidic gases from air; 2) modification of process and chemistry to accommodate widely-used nonwoven finishing equipment; 3) prototype and validate filters for commercial, residential, and industrial markets; and 4) produce IXFCs pilot, and subsequently, full-commercial scale.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this research is the development and commercialization of a low-cost technology enabling improved protection of equipment, processes, and human health. Moreover, the technology incorporates an intuitive, vibrant color-changing feature to indicate if filters are working or need to be replaced?thereby improving user awareness of air quality, and simultaneously reducing waste due to early replacement and energy loss due to use of long-expired filters.
